brief_description: Report a crime emergency in progress.
detailed_description:
You can help prevent crime. If you see or hear a crime in progress or any situation needing emergency attention, call 911. Crimes reported most frequently to 911 include:

  • Shoplifting, mugging, or taking someone else's property without their permission.
  • Hitting, slapping, punching, or sexually assaulting another person.
  • Using physical force or weapons to take someone else’s property.
  • Entering a home or any other building with the intent of committing any crime.
  • Breaking, defacing, or destroying someone else's property without permission.
  • Holding or selling illegal drugs or prescription drugs without a prescription.

brief_description: Get information about tuberculosis screening and treatment.
detailed_description:
The City provides tuberculosis (TB) screening and treatment to eligible patients at its clinics and hospitals. Appointments are required.

As of January 1, 2015, New York City Health Department clinics will adopt new health insurance and billing practices in order to comply with State law and Medicaid rules. brief_description: Report discrimination to the Commission on Human Rights.
detailed_description:
You can report discrimination with the NYC Commission on Human Rights if you believe that you have been a victim of discrimination in employment, housing, or public accommodations or a discriminatory act committed by a member of the public. Discrimination includes the inability to access housing or public accommodations because of a disability, such as the lack of a wheelchair ramp or bars installed in a bathroom. Discrimination also includes bias-based attacks, threats, including threats of deportation by a landlord or employer, insults or interference with basic rights committed by a member of the public.

You can report discrimination based on:

  • Race/national origin/color
  • Religion/creed
  • Age
  • Alienage or citizenship status (non-citizen or immigration status)
  • Gender/gender identity/gender expression, including denial of bathroom access
  • Pregnancy/caring for a child or sick family member
  • Sexual orientation
  • Disability, including failure to accommodate
  • Marital/partnership Status
  • Military Service
  • Employment
    • Domestic violence/stalking/sex offense
    • Arrest/conviction records
    • Credit history
    • Salary History
  • Housing
    • Children living in the home
    • Source of household income/occupation
    • Domestic violence/stalking/sex offense

You can submit an inquiry about discrimination with the NYC Commission on Human Rights. Once the inquiry is submitted, they will contact you with more information.

Submit an inquiry about discrimination.

service_name: Food Cart Vendor License or Permit
brief_description: Apply for or renew a license or permit to sell food from a pushcart or truck, either seasonally or year-round. Schedule a pre-permit inspection.
detailed_description:
Food carts and trucks in the City must be licensed.

You must have a license, which is a photo ID badge, to run a food-selling business from a pushcart or truck, either year-round or seasonally. This license is called a Mobile Food Vendor Personal License. You must also have a decal permit for any pushcart or truck where food is sold. This decal permit is called a Mobile Food Vending Unit Permit.

New permits are available only to those licensed vendors who were placed on the Food Cart Waiting List and notified by the Department of Health to apply for the permit. If you are notified, you must file an application in person at the Department of Consumer Affairs (DCA) Licensing Center. You must then contact the Department of Health to schedule an inspection appointment and have a permit sticker affixed to the pushcart or truck.

The permit expires two years from the previous expiration date. The fee is $200 for a processing food unit and $75 for a non-processing food unit. Veterans do not have to pay the fee.

service_name: Contractor Guidelines for the Build It Back Repair Program
brief_description: Information for contractors requesting a DOB inspection for Build it Back properties.
detailed_description:
The Department of Buildings offers inspections for Build it Back properties. Contractors wishing to schedule inspections, should refer to the following procedures to set up appointments:

Plumbing Inspections
To schedule a plumbing inspection, call (212) 393-2550 and provide your Build it Back registration number. You will be given a confirmation number. You must then email DOB at BIBinspections@buildings.nyc.gov.  In your email, include 'Plumbing Inspection Request' in the subject line. In the body of the email, provide:
  • All contact information (contact person, company name, phone number, and email address)
  • Location information (borough, job address, BIN)
  • Job number
  • Build it Back registration number
  • DOB confirmation number
Construction and Electrical Inspections
To schedule an appointment, email BIBinspections@buildings.nyc.gov. In your email, include either 'Construction Inspection Request' or 'Electrical Inspection Request' in the subject line. In the body of the email, provide:
  • All contact information (contact person, company name, phone number, and email address)
  • Location information (borough, job address, and BIN)
  • Job number or electrical application number
  • Build it Back registration number
Boiler Inspections
To schedule a boiler inspection, submit an online inspection request using the Boiler Appointment Form, then email BIBinspections@buildings.nyc.gov. In your email, include 'Boiler Inspection Request'  in the subject line.  In the body of the email, provide:
  • All contact information (contact person, company name, phone number, and email address)
  • Location information (borough, job address, and BIN)
  • Application number
  • Build it Back registration number
The Department of Buildings will send you an appointment confirmation within 2 days of receiving your email. The scheduled date will be within 10 days of the receipt of your inspection request. 

Contractors must work with the property owner to provide access to the inspector.

service_name: Real Property Income and Expense (RPIE) Filing Information
brief_description: Help with the tax form that is required for most income-producing properties.
detailed_description:
The RPIE is used by the Department of Finance to determine the value and property tax for certain income-producing properties. The deadline to file RPIE-2015 is June 1, 2016.

If you own an income-producing property with an assessed value of more than $40,000, you must file an RPIE unless:

  • you are excluded by law, or
  • the property was purchased after May 1, 2016

If you do not file an RPIE or filed after the deadline, you will face a penalty.

brief_description: Get information about the New York State Truck Mileage Tax and the New York City Commercial Motor Vehicle Tax.
detailed_description:
Commercial motor vehicles are subject to the New York City Commercial Motor Vehicle Tax and the New York State Truck Mileage Tax.

The following commercial motor vehicles are subject to the Commercial Motor Vehicle Tax:

  • Non-passenger commercial motor vehicles that are principally used in the City (with 50% or more of their mileage during the year within the City) or in connection with a business carried on in the City
  • Motor vehicles regularly used in the City for the transportation of passengers, regardless of the mileage within the City

The HUT/Truck Mileage Tax is a weight-distance tax, computed based on mileage traveled by motor vehicles on New York State public highways at a rate determined by the weight of the motor vehicle. It is not imposed on travel on the portions of the New York State Thruway for which a toll is charged.

brief_description: CUNY Start provides intensive preparation in academic reading, writing, math, and college success.
detailed_description:
The CUNY Start program enrolls prospective CUNY students who have been accepted to college because they have a high school or high school equivalency diploma (GED or TASC) but are not ready for college-level work based on their scores on the CUNY Assessment Tests. 


After completing the CUNY Start program, you will begin your CUNY college courses the following semester. As a result of college transition, you are likely to reduce the time you spend in college remedial courses and to make a stronger transition to college credit courses. You will start credit courses better prepared to succeed and graduate.

brief_description: Schedule an inspection of scale used by retail stores or airports.
detailed_description:
The Department of Consumer Affairs inspects scales and measuring devices used by retail stores, including grocery stores and bodegas, and airports to make sure they are accurate. All markets must have a scale in their prepackaged food section.

  1. Businesses can request scale inspections in one of three ways: Online via nyc.gov/BusinessToolbox.
  2. Email scaleinspection@dca.nyc.gov 
  3. Fax (718) 349-2576

You will get a notification of your inspection date within 15 days of the City receiving your scale inspection request (five days if you have a previously condemned scale). A City inspector will visit your business location unless you are a Mobile Vendor. Average inspection time is 15 to 30 minutes per scale.

The City will place a current official seal on scales that pass inspection.

You cannot use scales that fail inspection.

brief_description: Get information about a lost, found, stray, or abandoned animal.
detailed_description:
Animal Care Centers of NYC (ACC) accepts reports of lost, found, stray, or abandoned animals.

If you have lost your pet or found someone else's pet, you can visit ACC's lost/found pet database to report your lost pet or see if someone has reported their pet lost. You can also visit the Brooklyn, Manhattan, or Staten Island ACC Care Centers to see if your pet is being held there. If you are going to a Care Center to claim your pet, bring proof of ownership such as a photo of your pet or a veterinarian record. There are fees involved in reclaiming a lost pet from the Care Center.

You can also report found stray dogs; ACC will dispatch a team to pick up that dog. When the ACC dispatch center is closed, you should either hold onto the dog or bring it to the nearest ACC Care Center or receiving center.

ACC does not pick up or respond to reports about healthy stray adult cats, but will respond to reports of abandoned kittens. Any found pet or stray dog or cat can be brought to an ACC Care Center or receiving center during business hours.

Reports of animals that seem to have been abandoned by their owner are also accepted. These pets may be tied up in public for a lengthy period of time, or left in homes unattended after owners move or go on vacation.

Always use caution around stray animals. To trap an animal that is not injured or rabid, hire a professional trapper by checking the Yellow Pages under Animal Removal or Exterminator. You can also find professional trappers on the internet.

brief_description: Information on measles and measles vaccination
detailed_description:
Measles is still common in many parts of the world, including countries in Europe, Asia, the Pacific, and Africa. The United States has also seen a high number of measles cases. The majority of people who get measles are unvaccinated.

Measles is highly contagious, causing high fever and rash all over the body. Infection can be serious and more severe in young infants, pregnant women who are not immune to measles, and persons with a weak immune system. 

Complications may include:

• Ear infection
• Diarrhea
• Pneumonia
• Brain inflammation
• Death

Measles vaccine is very effective and safe, with the benefits far outweighing any risks. Children should receive their first dose of MMR vaccine routinely at 12 months of age and their second dose between ages 4 and 6 years. 

Adults without documentation of either prior measles vaccination or an immunity to measles should contact their healthcare provider to ask about a blood test to see if they are immune or for vaccination information. There is no harm in receiving additional doses of MMR vaccine. 

You should contact your healthcare provider to check your vaccination status before international travel.

Health care providers can order posters and other related material.
web_keywords: measles, miesles, outbreak, out, break, vaccination, vaccine, shot, exposed, exposure, infectious, rash, fever, contagious, infected, disease, desease

brief_description: Get a copy of a birth certificate, correct or change a birth certificate, or check the status of a request.
detailed_description:
You can order a copy of a birth certificate for yourself or your child online. Online orders are securely processed through VitalChek. You can also order by mail or in person. For orders in person, you must bring valid ID.

Each copy of a birth certificate costs $15. Additional processing and shipping fees may apply depending on how you order. You should get your birth certificate within 30 days of ordering.

Learn about ordering online, by mail, or in person, as well as about the valid forms of ID necessary to order, or check the processing time for your order.

Check the status of a birth certificate ordered from VitalChek.

Correct a birth certificate.

Call 311 to order a copy of a birth certificate for a mentally incapacitated person.

Ordering a Letter of Exemplification

If you need a Letter of Exemplification, you must request a new Long Form, or Vault copy of your birth certificate. You can make this request online, by mail, or in person. When you place your order for the birth certificate, make sure you clearly explain the reason for your request, and the Health Department will determine if a Letter of Exemplification is needed. Both a Letter of Exemplification and a Long Form birth certificate are needed for certain overseas transactions, such as dual citizenship, marriage on foreign soil, adopting a child from another country, or buying foreign real estate. If you plan to use your birth certificate in a foreign country, you may need to have it authenticated through an Apostille or Certificate of Authentication.

Order online through VitalChek.

Get information about an Apostille or a Certificate of Authentication.

brief_description: Report food poisoning or unsanitary conditions where food is sold.
detailed_description:
You can make a complaint about food safety practices in service establishments, including unsanitary conditions, pets, and insect infestations. You can also report food poisoning from anything prepared by a commercial establishment, or from eating at parties, weddings, banquets, or other gatherings. Symptoms of food poisoning include vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps.

You can file a food safety complaint against:

  • Supermarkets
  • Farmers markets
  • Fish markets
  • Beverage stores
  • Bodegas
  • Warehouses
  • Delis
  • Bakeries
  • Cafeterias
  • Food carts (including Green Carts), stands, or trucks
  • Restaurants

If you are reporting food poisoning, you must indicate how many people became sick and the food that you think caused the illness. If possible, keep a sample of the food so it may be collected and tested.

The Department of Health will issue violations or warnings when appropriate.

service_name: Nurse Home Visit for Pregnant Women
brief_description: Get information about a home visit from a nurse to help a woman who is pregnant for the first time.
detailed_description:
Through the Nurse Family Partnership (NFP), the City arranges for nurses to visit first-time pregnant women at home.

brief_description: City residents convicted of an animal abuse crime must register with the NYC Animal Abuse Registry.
detailed_description:
The 2014 Animal Abuse Registration Act requires anyone living in New York City who is convicted of an animal abuse crime after October 2, 2014, and who is at least 18 years old at the time of conviction, to contact the City Health Department to be added to the NYC Animal Abuse Registry. This law also requires certain animal-related businesses and organizations to check the NYC Animal Abuse Registry and refuse to sell or transfer ownership of an animal to anyone listed in the Registry.

If you are required to register, you must contact the Health Department within 5 days of being released from incarceration, or within 5 days of sentencing if you were not incarcerated.

The registration period lasts for 5 years after sentencing or, if you were incarcerated, for 5 years after release from incarceration.

Failure to register as required may be punishable by up to a year in jail, a fine up to $1,000, or both.

brief_description: Report a problem with a sidewalk newsrack.
detailed_description:
Newspaper boxes, or newsracks, are allowed on City sidewalks.

They must be located:

  • Between 18 to 24 inches from the curb
  • 5 feet from a crosswalk or building canopy
  • Allow for an 8-foot wide unobstructed path on the sidewalk

There are no restrictions on the number of newspaper boxes allowed at one location.

You can report a newsrack that is:

  • Broken
  • Filled with garbage
  • In a bus stop, crosswalk, or roadway
  • Within 15 feet of a hydrant or news stand
  • On a sidewalk grating, cellar door, or utility cover
  • Less than 18 inches or more than 24 inches from the curb
  • Obstructing an 8-foot wide sidewalk path
  • Chained to a lamp post or City property
  • Not weighed down
  • Exceeding allowed dimensions

The Department of Transportation enforces the regulations on the placement and condition of newsracks.

brief_description: Get information on flood insurance policy rate changes.
detailed_description:
New flood insurance policy rates will take effect April 1, 2015. Primary residences will see a renewal increase of 18% of the current premium. If your home was substantially damaged in Superstorms Sandy or Irene, the policy renewal could increase by up to 25%. Second residences and businesses will see a policy renewal increase of up to 25%.

Residential and business owners will also pay a new surcharge called the 'Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014 (HFIAA).' The surcharge for primary residences is $25 and secondary residences and businesses will be charged $250. You will automatically be billed $250, the HFIAA second-home rate. If your residence is your primary home, your insurance agent will send you a notice to submit proof to verify your primary residence. You must submit verification of primary residence to your insurance agent within 30 days from the date of the notice. If you do not submit verification in this timeframe, you will have to pay the $250 rate.

To receive the $25 HFIAA surcharge rate, you must submit ONE of the following proofs of primary residence:

  • Driver's license
  • Automobile registration
  • Proof of insurance for a vehicle
  • Voter registration

service_name: Restore Gas to Buildings Affected by Hurricane Sandy
brief_description: Get information on how to restore gas to your building.
detailed_description:
If your gas was shut off as a result of the storm, you need to hire a licensed plumber to inspect your gas equipment.

If there was no damage to your gas equipment, your plumber must submit a letter to your utility company stating there are no problems with the gas equipment in order to have your gas restored. Your utility company will turn your gas back on after they receive the letter.

If there was damage to your gas equipment, your plumber must make the necessary repairs and submit a letter to your utility company certifying there was damage and the necessary repairs were made to have your gas restored. Your utility company will turn your gas back on after they receive the letter.

Your plumber can perform the repair work immediately without having to file an application or obtain permits from the Department of Buildings (DOB). However, the necessary applications must be filed with DOB within two business days of commencing work.

brief_description: Assistance and information about the new rent laws for tenants living in rent-regulated apartments in New York City.
detailed_description:
New York's rent laws will be extended for 4 years, and will be made retroactive to June 15th, 2015.

Additional reforms to strengthen these laws include:

  • The rent at which a vacant apartment can be deregulated will increase from $2,500 to $2,700 and the rent amount will be tied to the 1-year annual Rent Guidelines Board (RGB) increases beginning January 1, 2016.
  • Limits on vacancy allowances in apartments with 'preferential rents,' which are rents charged below the legal rent.
  • Limits on the amount of rent that landlords can charge tenants in order to receive reimbursement for Major Capital Improvements (MCIs) by extending the period that landlords can recover those costs from 84 months to 108 months for buildings over 35 units and 84 months to 96 months for buildings under 35 units.
  • An increase in civil penalties for landlords who harass tenants.

brief_description: Get information about how the Department of Probation supervises juvenile offenders on probation.
detailed_description:
The City offers information about the Department of Probation (DOP), which supervises juvenile offenders. DOP will supervise youth who have been placed on probation by a judge in the Family Court. Juvenile delinquents, who were age 7 through 15 at the time of arrest, can be placed under the supervision of DOP for up to two years.

The youth is assigned to a Probation Officer who ensures that he or she complies with the conditions set by the judge, including paying restitution to victims, community service, and drug treatment. The Probation Officer is also responsible for monitoring the probationer's adjustment at home and at school. When necessary, a violation of probation is filed and the youth is returned to the court.

brief_description: Information about a rent subsidy program for people currently in shelter.
detailed_description:
Living in Communities (LINC) is a limited rental assistance program for low-income families and single adults living in homeless or domestic violence shelters. Priority will be given to households that have lived in shelters the longest.

The general public and shelter residents cannot apply to this rent subsidy program.

People who are eligible will be referred to the program by the Department of Homeless Services.

Shelter residents can contact their shelter's housing specialist or case manager with any questions.

Fact Sheets are available for LINC clients and for interested landlords and brokers.

If you are a landlord or broker, you can submit an apartment available for rent to the LINC Program.

brief_description: City residents convicted of an animal abuse crime must register with the NYC Animal Abuse Registry.
detailed_description:
The 2014 Animal Abuse Registration Act requires anyone living in New York City who is convicted of an animal abuse crime after October 2, 2014, and who is at least 18 years old at the time of conviction, to contact the City Health Department to be added to the NYC Animal Abuse Registry. This law also requires certain animal-related businesses and organizations to check the NYC Animal Abuse Registry and refuse to sell or transfer ownership of an animal to anyone listed in the Registry.

If you are required to register, you must contact the Health Department within 5 days of being released from incarceration, or within 5 days of sentencing if you were not incarcerated.

The registration period lasts for 5 years after sentencing or, if you were incarcerated, for 5 years after release from incarceration.

Failure to register as required may be punishable by up to a year in jail, a fine up to $1,000, or both.

brief_description: Information about the cooperative and condominium abatement.
detailed_description:
There are several types of property tax abatements including the Cooperative and Condominium Abatement. A member of the board of directors, a managing agent, or another official representative of a cooperative or condominium building applies for this abatement. Owners must have purchased the apartment on or before January 5th to be credited with the abatement starting the following July.

Individual unit owners who want to apply for any of the NYC property tax exemptions should complete the Homeowner Tax Benefit Application.

• Eligible units in buildings where the 2016/17 application is postmarked on or before March 2, 2016 will start receiving benefits July 1, 2016.

• Eligible units in buildings where the application is postmarked after March 2, 2016 as well as eligible units in buildings that submit a 2017/18 application will start receiving their benefits on July 1, 2017.

brief_description: Use NYC Free Tax Prep services to file your personal income taxes online or in person for free.
detailed_description:
Depending on your income, you may may be able to use NYC Free Tax Prep services, which include online and in-person filing. Services begin in January 2017. The tax filing deadline is Tuesday, April 18, 2017.

The online service provides step-by-step instructions to help you prepare and file your tax return. Experts are also available by phone to answer your questions.

NYC Free Tax Prep sites are available throughout the city and offer different options, including:

  • In-person assistance: At most sites, an IRS certified VITA/TCE volunteer preparer will prepare your taxes for you. At some sites, a volunteer will help you do your own taxes online.
  • Drop-off service: At some sites, you can drop off your tax documents and pick up the completed return later.

In general, to use a free site, you must:

  • Earn $54,000 or less if you have children.
  • Earn $30,000 or less if you do not have children.
  • Have a Social Security number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number.
  • Bring all relevant tax documents to the site.
  • Have a valid email address if you do your own taxes online with help.

Some sites may have different income eligibility requirements. You should ask the site for more details, including if the site offers language assistance or is wheelchair accessible.

service_name: NYCHA Domestic Violence or Assault Transfer Program
brief_description: Get information about a program that helps victims of domestic violence, sexual abuse, or intimidation transfer to a different New York City Housing Authority housing development.
detailed_description:
The New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) Emergency Transfer Program allows tenants and their authorized family members to apply confidentially for transfers to developments located in another area of the city. Tenants and family members must be able to support the claim that they are the victim of domestic violence or sexual assault, or the scared witness of violence or assault.

If you qualify and want to apply for an emergency transfer, you must complete a transfer request form and return it to the Management Office at their development. Transfer request forms are available at NYCHA Management Offices.

brief_description: Get information about the Health Research Training Program.
detailed_description:
The Health Research Training Program is an internship program for students enrolled in undergraduate, graduate, or professional degree programs at accredited colleges or universities in the United States.

The program has three cycles each year, each with its own application deadline:

  • Spring (January - June); applications due November 15
  • Summer (June - August); applications due February 15
  • Fall (September - December); applications due August 15

The fall and spring sessions are open to New York City residents only. The summer session does not have a residency requirement.

Four to six weeks after the application deadline, you will get an email about your application status.

brief_description: Report of a damaged sewer line.
detailed_description:
The City inspects and replaces sewer and water mains located in the street on a set schedule and does not accept reports from the public.

Sewer problems on Roosevelt Island are handled differently than sewer problems in other parts of the City. A private company called the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation accepts reports about Roosevelt Island sewer problems.

A damaged sewer line that connects a house to a street is the responsibility of the property owner and not the City. A licensed plumber must be hired to make the repairs. A licensed plumber will obtain all necessary permits to properly repair the problem.

brief_description: Find a vehicle that may have been towed.
detailed_description:
Vehicles can be towed if they are parked illegally or if you owe more than $350 for parking tickets or camera violations that are in judgment. If your vehicle is towed due to parking tickets or camera violations, it does not matter whether it is parked on a public street or private property. Any vehicles registered under your name may be towed for judgment debt.

You can get information about towed vehicles, including the agency that towed the vehicle, the vehicle's current location, and payment options for outstanding fines, penalties or fees.

If your vehicle is towed, it may take up to two hours for it to be entered into the system. If your vehicle is not in the system and it has been less than two hours, check back again later. If it has been more than two hours, contact the police precinct where the vehicle was parked. You will be able to confirm that it was towed or report it as stolen.

brief_description: Get information about a program for overage and under-credited high school students who want to get a high school diploma.
detailed_description:
The City's Young Adult Borough Centers (YABC) help overage and under-credited high school students get a high school diploma.

YABC offer evening programs for high school students age 17 or older who have some of the credits they need to graduate (at least 17 credits) but might be considering dropping out because they are behind or they have adult responsibilities that make attending school in the daytime difficult.

Students earn a high school diploma from their sending high school once they have earned all of their credits and passed exams required for graduation at the YABC.

For more information and to find out if you are eligible, contact your school's Guidance Counselor.

brief_description: Get information about parking cards and where to buy them.
detailed_description:
The New York City Parking Card is a pre-paid card that can be used for parking at all New York City municipal parking fields, Muni-Meters, and selected electronic single-space meters located in Long Island City and Manhattan. You can purchase cards in $20, $50, and $100 denominations.

After you insert the card in the meter, it will deduct the amount needed to pay for parking. Each time you use the card, the new balance will be displayed. Parking cards do not expire, but you cannot refill cards after the original value that you purchased is exhausted.

You can purchase parking cards:
  • Online
  • By phone
  • By mail
  • At vending machines at 66 John Street in Manhattan and the Staten Island St. George Ferry Terminal

You can pay by credit card if you buy the card online or by phone. You can pay by check or money order if you buy the card by mail. You will receive the parking cards by mail or FedEx, and your signature may be required.

brief_description: Get information about storing or discarding a propane tank.
detailed_description:
The City regulates propane tank storage.

One or two family properties may store outdoors a maximum of two 20 pound cylinders.

Outdoor barbecue grills designed to use charcoal or electricity with a total grate area not exceeding 10 square feet may be installed, operated and maintained on any residential premises, provided that such barbecues are not installed or operated within 10 feet of any flammable waste or material.

Propane tanks (like those used in barbecues) are not collected by the Department of Sanitation because they can explode when compressed in a garbage truck. Used tanks should be exchanged when buying a new tank, or brought in to a hardware store or propane dealer for reuse or recycling. Scrap metal dealers may also accept used tanks for recycling.

brief_description: Get information about what to do with an unwanted newborn or baby.
detailed_description:
New York State’s Abandoned Infant Protection Act allows a parent to abandon a newborn baby who is up to 30 days of age anonymously and without fear of prosecution, if the baby is abandoned in a safe manner. A parent is not guilty of a crime if the infant is left with an appropriate person or in a suitable location and the parent promptly notifies an appropriate person of the infant’s location.  A hospital, staffed police or fire station are examples of safe and suitable choices.

If the baby is older than 30 days, you may go to an Administration for Children's Services (ACS) Field Office to talk about giving someone else custody of the child or giving up your parental rights.

detailed_description:

service_name: Water Service Shut-Off for Residential or Commercial Property
brief_description: Request to turn off water service at a residential or commercial property.
detailed_description:
If you are a property owner and need to have your water service shut off, you have to contact a licensed plumber. The plumber will dig in the street to break the property's water service line connection to the DEP water main. Water charges will stop when the connection to the water main is broken.

The City does not provide a water shut-off service.

If you want to shut off your water temporarily, you can close the house control valve to stop water from flowing while you repair leaks or do renovations. You should have your plumber turn the water back on after repairs are completed.

Your property will continue to be charged for being connected to DEP water mains, but you may be billed at the current minimum billing rate.

brief_description: Request an on-site Fire Safety Director test.
detailed_description:
A candidate's supervisor (designated by the building owner) must make the request to schedule an on-site Fire Safety Director test. Candidates cannot schedule their own tests.

Qualifications

To qualify for the Fire Safety Director on-site test, the candidate must:

  • Pass the Fire Safety Director computer exam
  • Pass a 20-hour certified Fire Safety Director course
  • Receive a Certificate of Completion

Once all information is verified and qualified by the Certificate of Fitness Unit, the candidate has 1 year to take the on-site exam.

Exam Request

Before requesting an on-site exam, the supervisor must:

  • Ensure the candidate is qualified by the Certification Unit
  • Ensure the buidling has a Fire Safety and Evacuation Plan on file with FDNY
You can request an exam by emailing High-Rise@fdny.nyc.gov, with the subect line 'FSD On-Site request/Candidate's Last Name, First Name/Premises Address.' In the email, you should also include:
  • Premises information, such as the type (ie, hotel, office), the address, Building ID Number, and any Also Known As addresses.
  • Candidate's Information, including social security number and Certificate of Fitness number, if the candidate is certified at other premises.
  • Additional requirements, including if the exam must take place outside of the regular start time, Monday-Thursday, from 10 AM to noon.
  • Supervisor's name, title, business address, contact phone number, and email address.

Exam Cancellation

All requests for cancellations must be submitted via email to High-Rise@fdny.nyc.gov within 72 hours of the date of the exam. Please note 'Request for On-Site Exam Cancellation' in the subject of the email. The email should also include the candidate's name, social security number, exam date, and premises address. This information will help expedite the cancellation.

In the case of hardship, the supervisor can request an emergency overtime test Monday to Friday after 5 PM, or on Saturday. You must agree to cover additional overtime expenses.

No more than two candidates can be scheduled per day during normal business hours and on Saturdays. Only one candidate can be scheduled per day during evening hours.

brief_description: Get help for pregnant or parenting adolescents, including day care and information about educational rights.
detailed_description:
The City provides a variety of services for young people who are pregnant or parenting.

Assistance is available to help young mothers and fathers under age 21 manage their new concerns, take control of their lives, and learn how to provide better futures for themselves and their children.

Assistance is also available to adolescents who have had a miscarriage or whose child was placed in foster care, as well as to the brothers and sisters of the young parent.

To be eligible for this assistance under the Teen Age Services Act, either the mother-to-be, father-to-be, mother, father, or child must be receiving Medicaid benefits.

Case managers can help pregnant or parenting young people obtain the following:

  • Public benefits such as food stamps and WIC (the Women, Infants, and Children program)

  • Abstinence and family planning services

As of December 1, 2015, the City requires chain food service establishments and mobile food vendors with 15 or more locations nationwide to post a sodium warning icon next to menu items that contain 2,300 milligrams of sodium or more. The icon must be shown on all menu boards and menus, on food items displayed for sale with a food item tag, and on menu boards at or before a drive-through window.

service_name: Request Lead Test Kit for Drinking Water
brief_description: Request a kit to test drinking water for high levels of lead.
detailed_description:
You can request a free kit through the Free Residential Lead Testing Program to test your drinking water for high levels of lead. Lead usually enters drinking water when plumbing that contains lead corrodes. Lead does not have any color or smell. You can file a water complaint if your drinking water is not clear (has color) or has an odor or smell.

The Department of Environmental Protection will test your drinking water sample only for lead and nothing else. This kit is for use in private residences only. It cannot be used to meet the lead testing requirements of day care centers or other businesses.

You can order only one kit at a time. If you are a landlord who wants to order more than one kit for your building, you must make a separate request for each apartment.

To apply for a Place of Assembly Certificate of Operation, download the PA1 form online or pick it up at a Department of Buildings (DOB) Borough Office.

The Department of Buildings performs an inspection when you are first issued a Place of Assembly Certificate of Operation. This Certificate does not expire. Before the end of the first year after the Certificate is issued, the Fire Department must perform an inspection. brief_description: Pay a property tax bill.
detailed_description:
You can pay property taxes and other property-related charges by mail, in person, and online. CityPay, the online payment system, supports Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari, Google Chrome, and Internet Explorer version 9.0 and higher.

If you prefer to pay by mail, you can mail your payment with the coupon on your Property Tax Bill. Please write your borough, block, and lot number on any payment that you mail along with the tax period the payment is for.

If you use the U.S. Post Office, mail payment to:

    NYC Department of Finance
    P.O. Box 680
    Newark, NJ 07101-0680

 

If you use a private overnight delivery service, mail your payment to:

    NYC Department of Finance
    c/o First Data
    1150 South Avenue, Suite 201
    Staten Island, NY 10314-3404
    Phone number for the tracking slip: (718) 355-6516

brief_description: Apply for or renew a permit to install an X-ray machine or other radiation producing medical equipment.
detailed_description:
The Radiation Equipment Permit expires after 2 years. About 3 months before your permit expires, the City will send you a permit renewal notice.

Beginning July 1, 2017, dentist and podiatry offices must submit proof of an inspection within the previous 5 years with their renewal documents. Proof is the inspection form given to the facility when an inspection is completed. The form identification number is either RC-43 or RC-45.

You can renew in person at the Department of Consumer Affairs (DCA) Licensing Center in Manhattan or at the NYC Small Business Support Center in Queens.

Dentists and Podiatrists will need to upload an electronic copy of proof of inspection to renew online.
web_keywords: radiation

brief_description: Complaint about a missing, fake or incorrect food establishment letter grade.
detailed_description:
You can report a problem with a food establishment posting a letter grade, including:

  • Not posting a grade
  • Improperly posting a grade sign
  • Grade poster is damaged
  • Posting an incorrect or counterfeit letter grade.

Having the nine-digit Card Number noted on the grade sign is helpful for investigating the complaint.

Genuine letter grade cards should be located in the window or in front of a restaurant. They are made of card stock, not paper, and would not be posted in the dining, food preparation, or counter areas of a restaurant.

brief_description: Information about the Zika virus.
detailed_description:
People usually get the Zika virus through a mosquito bite, but not a bite from any mosquito.

Zika is affecting parts of Central and South America, Mexico, the Caribbean, and other places listed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The type of mosquito linked to the current outbreak lives in these places. It has not been found in New York City.

The most common Zika symptoms are:

  • Fever
  • Rash
  • Joint pain
  • Conjunctivitis (red eyes)

brief_description: Information about New York City's Identification Card.
detailed_description:
The IDNYC program offers a photo identification card for residents of New York City who are at least 14 years old. This municipal ID card connects New Yorkers to services, programs, and benefits, regardless of immigration status, homeless status, or gender identity.

Veterans can also request the IDNYC card with a special Veteran Designation that offers exclusive benefits.

You can apply for the card online or in person. Appointments are required. You will need to bring documents to prove your identity and that you live in New York City.

If you require a reasonable accommodation, IDNYC will contact you about your request.

IDNYC Website

You can use the IDNYC website to:

  • submit your first application and schedule your appointment
  • check your application status
  • make a change to card information or replace a lost or stolen card
  • re-apply if you were denied
  • use the document calculator to make sure you have all the documents needed to apply

brief_description: Get information about a program to reduce traffic congestion, increase pedestrian safety, and improve travel time in Manhattan.
detailed_description:
THRU Streets are designed to reduce traffic congestion, increase pedestrian safety, and improve travel time in Midtown Manhattan. During the peak weekday hours of 10 AM to 6 PM, motorists are not allowed to make most turns off the following nine crosstown streets between 3rd and 6th Avenues:
  • 36th Street
  • 37th Street
  • 45th Street
  • 46th Street
  • 49th Street
  • 50th Street
  • 53rd Street
  • 54th Street
  • 60th Street

Turns are permitted onto Park Avenue in both directions. This exception does not apply to 45th Street, which does not have access to Park Avenue.

Traffic signs identify turning restrictions and related regulations.

brief_description: Make a complaint about a business that gives an incorrect or illegal receipt.
detailed_description:
You can make a complaint about businesses that give illegal receipts or fail to give a correct receipt.

Consumer protection laws require businesses to offer you a receipt on purchases of $20 or more. For purchases between $5 and $20, a receipt must be given if you request one. All receipts must show the total amount paid, including a separate statement of tax, date, actual business name and address of the merchant, and the make and model of audio, photographic, and video equipment. Receipts must be itemized.

By law, all businesses that accept payment by credit card must remove the expiration date and all but the last five digits of the credit card number on the customer copy of receipts.

brief_description: Information about Leptospirosis, a bacterial disease associated with rat urine.
detailed_description:
Leptospirosis is a bacterial disease that is most commonly spread by rats. Contact with rat urine can lead to infection.

The bacteria can enter the body through:
     • eyes
     • nose
     • mouth
     • wounds and cuts in the skin

Some people who are infected may have no symptoms. Others may experience mild illness with:
     • fever
     • headache
     • chills
     • muscle aches
     • vomiting 
     • diarrhea

If you have these symptoms, see a doctor as soon as possible. Tell your doctor that you may have been exposed to leptospirosis.

For more information about this disease call 311.

brief_description: Report a building, business, or other public space, such as a park or library, with inadequate access for people with disabilities.
detailed_description:
You can report non-complying egress, parking facilities, and bathrooms that do not meet local requirements for accessibility for people with disabilities.

Buildings that were built before 1987 are exempt from the law governing accessibility for disabled people (Local Law 58/1987). They must follow the law if renovations or alterations made on the building after 1987 cost more than half of the building's replacement value.

The New York City Commission's Human Rights Law requires that reasonable accommodations be made to all residential buildings and public spaces to make them accessible to people with disabilities. These reasonable accommodations cannot pose an undue hardship to the building owner. Reasonable accommodations often involve architectural modifications, including ramps, electronic doors, or handrails. The Human Rights Law does not consider the age of the building in requiring modifications.

service_name: Fallen Tree or Branch Removal Request
brief_description: Request the removal of fallen, dead, or damaged trees or branches.
detailed_description:
The Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR) removes street trees and large branches that have fallen to the ground in front of houses, in parks, and in other public places. DPR also removes trees or branches that are blocking sidewalks or streets, as well as branches that are cracked or hanging and about to fall. Removal of trees, branches, and related debris may be delayed during a storm if the branches are not blocking streets or sidewalks.

Fallen Tree
Tree in poor condition
Split Tree Trunk

Trees that are located along streets in front of houses will be investigated and removed if necessary. DPR also removes dead trees from parks and other public spaces.

DPR is not responsible for:

  • Any non-City tree that falls on private property
  • Any small non-City tree branch that falls on private property
  • Any tree that is located on private property

Property owners must consult with a private landscape contractor to arrange for the removal of non-City trees or tree branches. Landscape contractors are listed in the yellow pages.

Property owners are responsible for knowing whether a tree is on their property or on the City's property. Trees can appear to be growing on your property but actually be on City property. Reference your title survey to verify property lines before removing a tree or conducting any tree work on or around trees in your front yard.

service_name: Middle Class Child Care Loan Program
brief_description: Program for middle class families to apply for a low-interest loan for child care and get free financial counseling.
detailed_description:
The City Council, in partnership with the credit union Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners, is offering low-interest loans to eligible families to pay for child care. You must schedule an appointment at a New York City Financial Empowerment Center run by Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners to learn more about the Middle Class Child Care Loan Program.

To qualify for a loan, you must:
• Have annual income of $80,000 to $200,000
• Get free one-on-one professional financial counseling
• Have a credit score of at least 620
• Have children between the ages of 2 and 4 who will attend day care

In the first year of the program, Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners can make loans to 40 eligible families. If you are approved:
• You can get a loan of up to $11,000 to pay for child care
• Payment will be made directly to the day care provider
• Interest on the loan is 6%. You can make interest-only payments until your child reaches kindergarten age.

brief_description: Get information about water and sewer bills, including payment and dispute information.
detailed_description:
You can pay your water and sewer bill online, over the phone, by mail, or in person.

Visit www.nyc.gov/dep to sign up for 'My DEP Account' to:

  • Track your water use
  • Pay your bill online
  • Sign up for paperless billing
  • Sign up for online leak notifications

You may also contact DEP Customer Service by email at customerservice@dep.nyc.gov or by phone at (718) 595-7000 for assistance and information with the following:

  • Change the name on your water bill
  • Arrange for a final meter reading
  • Obtain your current balance
  • Obtain due dates
  • Request information regarding the calculation of your water bill
  • Dispute the charges on your water bill
  • Request additional information

You can also update owner contact information by completing and returning the Customer Registration Form.

The DEP Customer Service Call Center hours are Monday to Friday, 9 AM to 6 PM, and Saturday, 9 AM to 2 PM.

brief_description: Report a curb that is damaged, painted, or illegally cut for a driveway.
detailed_description:
The curb is considered to be a part of the roadway and owned by the City of New York. The City accepts reports of curb conditions. You can report a curb that is damaged, illegally painted by a property owner to discourage parking, or illegally cut for a driveway. You must provide the exact street address of the property where the condition exists.

Property owners should ensure the curb is maintained, as it:
â  Facilitates the life of the sidewalk
â  Protects the sidewalks from vehicular traffic
â  Channels water properly to catch basins
â  Prevents erosion and ponding

Missing or damaged curbs should be replaced at the same time as the sidewalk is repaired, reconstructed, or installed.

The City will inspect the condition of the curb and sidewalk at the location. Property owners are responsible for the maintenance and repair of their sidewalk. If a sidewalk is found to be defective, the property owner will be notified.

service_name: Electric Vehicles in New York City
brief_description: Information about the City's support of electric vehicle use.
detailed_description:
New York City supports the use of electric vehicles, which offer a cleaner form of transportation than gasoline or diesel-fueled vehicles.

In addition to reducing fuel costs, electric vehicles emit 70% less carbon dioxide emissions than an average vehicle.  Pure battery electric vehicles also do not pollute from tailpipes.  This reduces overall pollution and makes New York City streets cleaner.

brief_description: Get information about the requirement to install carbon monoxide detectors.
detailed_description:
The City requires the installation of carbon monoxide detectors (alarms) in all new and existing one- and two-family homes, apartment buildings, and hotels. Carbon monoxide detectors are also required in dormitories, nursing homes, and schools. The carbon monoxide detectors must be installed within 15 feet of the primary entrance to each sleeping room. This applies to all multiple dwellings and one-family and two-family homes.

The City may not issue a Temporary Certificate of Occupancy or a final Certificate of Occupancy unless carbon monoxide detectors are installed in accordance with the law.

Carbon monoxide detectors are required to be replaced as their useful life expires, according to the manufacturer's instructions and based on the original date of installation. The replacement device must be a model that has an end-of-life alarm.

While owners are required to install and replace carbon monoxide detectors, tenants are responsible for maintaining them and changing the batteries. Tenants must pay the owner $25 when the owner installs a new carbon monoxide detector, replaces a carbon monoxide detector that has reached the end of its useful life, or replaces one that the tenant lost or damaged. Tenants have up to 1 year to make the payment.

The City is conducting an electric taxi program with selected taxis running completely on electricity for 1 year. This pilot program is the first step toward the goal of having one-third of the City's taxis electric by 2020. It is designed to test the effectiveness of electric taxis in the City.

brief_description: Program bringing fruits and vegetables to participating preschools.
detailed_description:
Farm to Preschool brings fresh, locally grown fruits and vegetables to select New York City preschools, giving parents, staff and community members weekly access to fresh produce.

Each week, from July through November, parents, staff and community members can purchase a produce box with a variety of locally grown fruits and vegetables at participating preschools. Prices range from $12 to $14, and Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) cards, Health Bucks, cash, credit and debit are accepted.

Farm to Preschool also provides nutrition education and on-site food demonstrations. Lessons include the benefits of eating fresh fruits and vegetables and how to prepare simple, healthy recipes with locally grown produce.

brief_description: A free business training program for NYCHA residents to start and grow food businesses in New York City.
detailed_description:
The NYCHA Food Business Pathways Program (FBP) is a free business training program that helps NYCHA and NYCHA Section 8 residents start and grow food businesses in New York City.

Residents who are accepted into the program receive:

  • A free 8-week intensive business course tailored specifically to meet the needs of NYCHApreneurs (NYCHA Entrepreneurs)
  • Free licenses and permits
  • Group and one-on-one business coaching designed to move a business forward
  • An opportunity to compete for the chance to receive one of five free incubator spaces for 5 months, as they work to use their education. All participants will receive assistance to secure alternative space in which to operate their food businesses.
Minimum Basic Requirements:
  • Be a NYCHA or NYCHA Section 8 resident, 18 years of age or older
  • Attend all 14 program sessions from 6 PM to 8 PM over a 10-week period
  • Have a passion for the food business

service_name: Ready New York Program or Guide
brief_description: Get a guide on what to do in an emergency, including a flood.
detailed_description:
The City provides Ready New York guides for information about how to prepare for emergencies in New York City. The guides also contain information about how to put together a Go Bag and an emergency supply kit.:

Select guides are available in English, Spanish, Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, Haitian Creole, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian, Urdu, and Yiddish, as well as others. A pocket guide, quick reference card, or audio version for the hard of hearing is also available. In addition to the general Ready New York Guide, there are specialized guides for:

  • Creating an Emergency Plan
  • Emergency preparedness
  • Pocket-Sized Emergency Preparedness
  • Businesses
  • Kids
  • Seniors and people with disabilities
  • Pets
  • Pandemic flu
  • Flooding situations
  • Hurricanes
  • Staying healthy in the summer heat

If you need more than 50 copies of a Ready New York Guide, send a request by mail to:

Ready New York Program
New York City Emergency Management
165 Cadman Plaza East
Brooklyn, NY 11201

To request hard copies, you can send an email to readyny@oem.nyc.gov.

An 11 minute video on emergency preparedness is also available.

brief_description: Get information about becoming an auxiliary police officer.
detailed_description:
You can get information about becoming an auxiliary police officer.

Auxiliary police are uniformed members of the NYPD who help deter crime through regular patrols and by providing assistance at major incidents. The program welcomes people with a sense of community and public service, or who have an interest in a future career in law enforcement.

Auxiliary police officers must:

  • Be at least 17 years of age
  • Live in New York City or work in New York City and live in one of the six authorized surrounding counties (Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange or Putnam)
  • Be in good health
  • Be able to read and write English
  • Never have been convicted of a felony or arrested for a serious crime that would prevent acceptance
  • Have U.S. citizenship, a valid visa, or an alien registration card

service_name: Sidewalk Cleaning Enforcement or Sticker Request
brief_description: Get information about when summonses may be issued for dirty sidewalks and gutters. Request a sticker listing enforcement hours.
detailed_description:
You can get information on sidewalk cleaning enforcement times. Policies differ for commercial and residential properties.

Residential property owners must clean the sidewalks adjoining their property and 18 inches from the curb into the street. Sanitation agents can only issue violations for dirty sidewalks in front of residential property from 8 AM to 9 AM and from 6 PM to 7 PM, 7 days a week. Enforcement times may differ for properties used for both commercial and residential purposes.

Commercial property owners must clean the sidewalks adjoining their property and 18 inches from the curb into the street. Enforcement times are limited to two 1-hour periods per day and vary according to which sanitation section the address is located in.

Business owners can also request a commercial enforcement routing sticker, which lists the times during which the Department of Sanitation can issue tickets for dirty sidewalks and gutters.

If you own a building with one or more cooling towers, you must develop, implement, and update as necessary a written Maintenance Program and Plan (MPP) for each cooling tower.

MPPs must be prepared by a qualified individual and be maintained on site or in an adjacent location on the same campus, complex, or lot. MPPs must be made accessible for use and inspection by any City oversight agency.

brief_description: Get information about the NYC Craft Entrepreneurship Program.
detailed_description:
The City has launched the NYC Craft Entrepreneurship Program, designed to help crafters sell their products and earn more money.

The training will be held in all five boroughs. Each class is made up of five class sessions, covering subjects such as:

  • Becoming an entrepreneur
  • Branding and marketing
  • Product photography
  • Day-to-day business strategy
  • Planning for growth
In order to be eligible, applicants must:
  • Have at least one handmade craft item ready to sell
  • Commit to attending four weeknight classes and one Saturday class (about 12 hours total)
  • Reside in New York City
  • Have never made any sales on Etsy.com
  • Have a credit card and checking account (necessary for sales transactions)
  • Have regular access to a computer with an Internet connection

The NYC Craft Entrepreneurship Program is provided by the NYC Department of Small Business Services in partnership with Etsy, and funded by Citi Community Development.

brief_description: Get information about Medicare, including enrollment, card replacement, Medicare Savings Programs, and Medicare Part D drug plan information.
detailed_description:
Medicare offers healthcare assistance for seniors age 65 and over and people with disabilities. You can get information and assistance with Medicare, including enrollment, coverage, billing, ordering a replacement Medicare card, and various Medicare Savings Programs.

Through the Medicare Part D program, Medicare offers prescription drug insurance to Medicare participants. Medicare Part D Enrollment sites help seniors age 65 and older and disabled people with Medicare with:

  • Prescription drug questions
  • Signing up for a Medicare Part D prescription drug plan
  • Problems with a selected drug plan
  • Assistance for those who have just become eligible for Medicare or who will become eligible for Medicare soon

The Health Insurance Information Counseling and Assistance Program (HIICAP) offers free counseling about Medicare to seniors and people with disabilities.

You can also attend a monthly orientation class if you're new to Medicare or will soon be eligible. The free class is held in Manhattan. Registration is required. You can get the current schedule or reserve a place by emailing ehausman@aging.nyc.gov or calling (212) 442-0922.

You can report unusual Medicare claims and possible Medicare fraud to the state-wide Senior Medicare Patrol - Medicare Fraud Hotline at (877) 678-4697.

brief_description: Information on the Rockaway Delivery Lateral gas pipeline project.
detailed_description:
The Rockaway Delivery Lateral is a 3-mile pipeline being constructed from a location south of the Marine Parkway Bridge interchange, under Jacob Riis Park to an offshore location in the Atlantic Ocean. The project will provide natural gas from the existing Transco pipeline in New York Bay for the Rockaways, including areas of Brooklyn and Queens.

Construction activity be visible from the shore. This activity is temporary and includes equipment in the water. The area is safe for normal use, and there will not be any beach closures during construction. The project is expected to be completed in the spring of 2015.

For additional information, call the project's hotline at (866) 455-9103. You can also email any questions to pipelineexpansion@williams.com.

brief_description: Information for someone who is giving away a pet.
detailed_description:
Animal Care Centers of NYC (ACC) does not pick up unwanted pets from your home. ACC will accept pets, including dogs, cats, rabbits, or other animals that are kept as pets at Care Centers for a fee. If the animal cannot be adopted or placed with a New Hope Partner, it may be humanely euthanized.

The fees are:

  • $35 to offer for adoption
  • $125 to euthanize

All forms of payment are accepted.

If you request adoption but the animal must later be euthanized, your cost will remain $35.

brief_description: Information about the Ebola virus.
detailed_description:
The often fatal Ebola virus is spread through broken skin or through your eyes, nose, or mouth if they are in direct contact with the body fluids of a person sick with Ebola. It cannot be spread through the air or simply by being near someone who is infected.

The disease usually starts with an abrupt fever, possibly with headache and joint and muscle aches anywhere from 2 to 21 days after exposure. People only become contagious after they begin to have symptoms, such as fever.

Ebola has been eradicated in some countries. There are no current reports of Ebola in the United States.

Health care providers can order travel triage posters to help inform patients. The posters are available in multiple languages.

brief_description: Get information about the federal Job Corps program.
detailed_description:
You can get information about Job Corps, a free education and vocational training program. Program participants learn a trade, earn a high school diploma or GED/TASC, and are paid a monthly allowance. Job Corps provides job placement services, as well as career counseling and transition support for its graduates.

To enroll in Job Corps, you must meet the following requirements:

  • Be age 16 to 24
  • Be a United States citizen or legal resident
  • Meet income requirements as determined by the U.S. Department of Labor

brief_description: Prevent pregnancy after a condom has broken or after unprotected sex.
detailed_description:
If unintended pregnancy is a concern, EC, or Emergency Contraception, is a safe way to prevent pregnancy after a condom has broken or if you had unprotected sex. Emergency Contraception can reduce your risk of pregnancy up to five days after unprotected sex. The faster you use it after sex the more likely it is to prevent pregnancy.

If you are 15 or older you can buy Emergency Contraception at a pharmacy without a prescription. The cost ranges from $40 to $50. Free Emergency Contraception is available at any of the Health Department's STD Clinics. It can be obtained without parental consent. No appointment is needed.

If a condom broke, keep the condom wrapper and any other condoms in the box or package. You should report the breakage to the phone number on the package.

brief_description: Get a brochure about newborn and baby safety.
detailed_description:
The City provides information about how to keep newborns and babies safe.

The Your New Baby brochure provides general information for parents about keeping new babies healthy.

The Take Good Care of Your Baby brochure provides information about keeping a young child safe. Topics include safe sleeping, choosing a caregiver, preventing Shaken Baby Syndrome, help for parents with alcohol or drug problems, window guards, water safety, and more.

The Babies Sleep Safest Alone brochure explains why it is best for a baby to sleep alone. It also provides information on preventing injuries and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

The Prevent Child Abuse New York brochure provides information about Shaken Baby Syndrome and how to prevent it. It also provides referrals for families in need of parenting support or education.

brief_description: Make a complaint about the condition of a private waste transfer station.

Complaints and potential violations include:

brief_description: Replace your benefit card, check your balance, or change your PIN for Medicaid, cash assistance, or food stamps.
detailed_description:
If your Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) card for Medicaid, Cash Assistance, or Food Stamps was lost, stolen, or printed with incorrect information, you can get a replacement. Replacement cards can only be mailed to the address on record.

It will take between 7 and 10 business days for you to get the card.

If your card is for more than one benefit, you only have to submit one replacement request.

  • If your card includes Cash Assistance, select Cash Assistance below.
  • If your card is for Medicaid and Food Stamps, select Food Stamp below.

brief_description: Register as a general contractor who works on one, two, or three family homes.
detailed_description:
All general contractors seeking permits to build one-, two-, or three-family homes must be registered with the Department of Buildings (DOB). DOB will only give registered general contractors building permits for these projects.

Unregistered individuals or entities found building one-, two-, or three-family homes may face violations, stop work orders, criminal charges, and the seizure of vehicles and construction tools.

service_name: Electric Vehicles in New York City
brief_description: Information about the City's support of electric vehicle use.
detailed_description:
New York City supports the use of electric vehicles, which offer a cleaner form of transportation than gasoline or diesel-fueled vehicles.

In addition to reducing fuel costs, electric vehicles emit 70% less carbon dioxide emissions than an average vehicle.  Pure battery electric vehicles also do not pollute from tailpipes.  This reduces overall pollution and makes New York City streets cleaner.

service_name: HIV Test and Treatment for Teens
brief_description: Get HIV and AIDS counseling, testing, and treatment services for teens.
detailed_description:
You can get testing for HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases at a clinic especially for teens.

You can get sexual health services at a clinic without your parents' permission or knowledge. Services are confidential, free or very low-cost, and open to all. You will be helped regardless of your immigration status.

As of January 1, 2015, New York City Health Department clinics will adopt new health insurance and billing practices in order to comply with State law and Medicaid rules. If you are 19 or older, STD clinic staff will ask for your health insurance information or a sliding scale fee based on your income and family size. If you do not have health insurance or cannot pay the fee, you can still get services. Your visit remains confidential.
